title: Q1: Question 5
content: A 100Hz sound wave has what wavelength?
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Sound is a mechanical wave that propagates as a longitudinal wave of pressure variations (compression and rarefaction) through a medium like air or water. Without a medium, there is no sound.

"Frequency is objective fact; pitch is subjective perception."
- Psychoacoustics

expert_quote.text: Frequency is objective fact; pitch is subjective perception.
expert_quote.author: Psychoacoustics

expert_explanation: Sound is a mechanical wave that propagates as a longitudinal wave of pressure variations (compression and rarefaction) through a medium like air or water. Without a medium, there is no sound.

title: Q2: Question 6
content: At 4 meters from a speaker (compared to 1 meter), level is:
explanation:
Expert Explanation: The speed of sound in air at 20°C is approximately 343 meters per second (1130 feet per second). Temperature affects this speed; sound travels faster in warm air and slower in cold air.

"The speed of sound varies with temperature, affecting outdoor delay times."
- System Technician

expert_quote.text: The speed of sound varies with temperature, affecting outdoor delay times.
expert_quote.author: System Technician

expert_explanation: The speed of sound in air at 20°C is approximately 343 meters per second (1130 feet per second). Temperature affects this speed; sound travels faster in warm air and slower in cold air.

title: Q3: Question 9
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Reflection occurs when sound bounces off a surface. Hard, flat surfaces (concrete, glass) create strong specular reflections. Irregular surfaces scatter sound (diffusion).

"Early reflections define the character of a small room."
- Control Room Design

expert_quote.text: Early reflections define the character of a small room.
expert_quote.author: Control Room Design

expert_explanation: Reflection occurs when sound bounces off a surface. Hard, flat surfaces (concrete, glass) create strong specular reflections. Irregular surfaces scatter sound (diffusion).

title: Q4: Question 2
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Absorption prevents sound from reflecting by converting the acoustic energy into heat (via friction inside porous materials like rockwool). It is the primary tool for controlling reverb time.

"Absorption removes energy from the room, reducing decay time."
- Studio Builder

expert_quote.text: Absorption removes energy from the room, reducing decay time.
expert_quote.author: Studio Builder

expert_explanation: Absorption prevents sound from reflecting by converting the acoustic energy into heat (via friction inside porous materials like rockwool). It is the primary tool for controlling reverb time.

title: Q5: Question 6
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Diffusion spreads reflected sound energy evenly in multiple directions, maintaining the 'liveliness' of the room without causing direct echoes or standing waves.

"A good diffuser makes a small room sound larger."
- Acoustic Goal

expert_quote.text: A good diffuser makes a small room sound larger.
expert_quote.author: Acoustic Goal

expert_explanation: Diffusion spreads reflected sound energy evenly in multiple directions, maintaining the 'liveliness' of the room without causing direct echoes or standing waves.

title: Q6: Question 5
content: A room that's 5 meters long has its first mode at approximately:
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Standing waves (Room Modes) occur when sound waves bounce between parallel walls and their wavelength matches the room dimensions, causing massive volume buildups (peaks) and cancellations (nulls) at specific frequencies.

"Standing waves are stationary patterns of high and low pressure."
- Physics Fact

expert_quote.text: Standing waves are stationary patterns of high and low pressure.
expert_quote.author: Physics Fact

expert_explanation: Standing waves (Room Modes) occur when sound waves bounce between parallel walls and their wavelength matches the room dimensions, causing massive volume buildups (peaks) and cancellations (nulls) at specific frequencies.

title: Q7: Question 2
explanation:
Expert Explanation: RT60 represents the time it takes for sound pressure to decrease by 60dB after the source stops. A control room typically aims for an RT60 of 0.2-0.4 seconds (tight/dry).

"RT60 defines the reverberation time for a 60dB decay."
- Sabine's Formula

expert_quote.text: RT60 defines the reverberation time for a 60dB decay.
expert_quote.author: Sabine's Formula

expert_explanation: RT60 represents the time it takes for sound pressure to decrease by 60dB after the source stops. A control room typically aims for an RT60 of 0.2-0.4 seconds (tight/dry).

title: Q8: Question 10
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Bass traps are thick absorbers placed in corners where low-frequency energy creates maximum pressure. They are essential because standard thin foam panels do almost nothing below 300Hz.

"Velocity absorbers work best away from walls; pressure absorbers on walls."
- Acoustic Physics

expert_quote.text: Velocity absorbers work best away from walls; pressure absorbers on walls.
expert_quote.author: Acoustic Physics

expert_explanation: Bass traps are thick absorbers placed in corners where low-frequency energy creates maximum pressure. They are essential because standard thin foam panels do almost nothing below 300Hz.

title: Q9: Question 8
explanation:
Expert Explanation: The primary goal of acoustic panels at the 'First Reflection Points' (mirror points) is to create a Reflection-Free Zone (RFZ) at the listening position, improving stereo imaging.

"Egg cartons do nothing for isolation."
- Debunked Myth

expert_quote.text: Egg cartons do nothing for isolation.
expert_quote.author: Debunked Myth

expert_explanation: The primary goal of acoustic panels at the 'First Reflection Points' (mirror points) is to create a Reflection-Free Zone (RFZ) at the listening position, improving stereo imaging.

title: Q10: Question 1
content: Near-field monitors are designed for listening at:
explanation:
Expert Explanation: Near-field monitors are designed to be listened to from a close distance (1-1.5m) to minimize the sound of the room acoustics. Far-field monitors are mounted in walls and interact more with the room.

"Ported speakers extend bass but can smear transients."
- Speaker Design

expert_quote.text: Ported speakers extend bass but can smear transients.
expert_quote.author: Speaker Design

expert_explanation: Near-field monitors are designed to be listened to from a close distance (1-1.5m) to minimize the sound of the room acoustics. Far-field monitors are mounted in walls and interact more with the room.
